title: 110_s3571
content:
The "Health Impact Assessments Act of 2008" or the "HIA Act of 2008" requires studies by the Government Accountability Office to identify best practices for assessing the planning and impact of land use, building design, and social policy on community health. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to determine best practices for using health impact assessments to promote health and reduce disparities through public policies. The study will also review the health consequences of Federal policies and programs. A report on the study's results must be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. States will review health consequences of Federal policies and programs, and consider health impact assessments for projects involving Federal funding or work. The Comptroller General will conduct a study, similar to the environmental impact statements process, and submit a report to Congress within one year. The National Demonstration Program is established under Section 3. The Secretary will award a grant to an institution of higher education to provide technical assistance, grants, and training on health impact assessments for community planning and policy making. The grant will also support the development of necessary data and evidence for health impact assessments and broad policy decisions. The Center will administer a demonstration grant program to consult with national organizations for health impact assessments. Eligible entities include state and local government departments for designing and implementing health impact assessments. Authorization of Appropriations:
- $1,000,000 for fiscal year 2009 for subsection (a), with additional funding for fiscal years 2010-2013.
- $4,000,000 for fiscal year 2009 for subsection (b), with additional funding for fiscal years 2010-2011. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will expand activities to improve public health and reduce disparities in land use, social policies, and health risks. This includes developing guidance for assessing public participation and health effects, expanding training efforts, and creating training tools. $1,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2009, with additional funding for fiscal years 2010-2013. The Act defines "built environment" as all buildings, spaces, and products created or modified by individuals, including homes, schools, workplaces, parks, transportation systems, and waste disposal sites. It also defines "health impact assessment" as analyzing the effects of a policy, program, or project on population health and identifying actions to manage those effects. The term "health impact assessment" involves objectively evaluating potential health effects of a project or policy and providing recommendations for improving health outcomes through collaboration, transparency, and accountability in policy making. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
